body_html: Thanks for explanation. Yep. But this makes it hard for someone who uses tf.pow in their code but still want to find out other NaNs, right? And it also feels a little uncomfortable to have different behaviors between tf.pow (y=2) and tf.square when using check_op.
body_text: Thanks for explanation. Yep. But this makes it hard for someone who uses tf.pow in their code but still want to find out other NaNs, right? And it also feels a little uncomfortable to have different behaviors between tf.pow (y=2) and tf.square when using check_op.
body: Thanks for explanation. Yep. But this makes it hard for someone who uses tf.pow in their code but still want to find out other NaNs, right? And it also feels a little uncomfortable to have different behaviors between tf.pow (y=2) and tf.square when using check_op.
